question: Should the EU, USA, and other Western donors refuse to fund any Palestinian government in which terrorist organizations participate?

content.source_1: Congressional Research Service (CRS), “U.S. Foreign Aid to the Palestinians” (R46274). https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/R/R46274 - Summarizes U.S. statutory and policy restrictions that limit or bar funding to any Palestinian government that includes designated terrorist organizations (e.g., Hamas), including the Palestinian Anti-Terrorism Act, the Taylor Force Act, and material support prohibitions. Provides the legal/policy rationale often cited by donors for withholding funds under such circumstances.
content.source_2: World Bank, “Economic Monitoring Report to the Ad Hoc Liaison Committee (AHLC), September 2023.” https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/westbankandgaza/publication/economic-monitoring-report-to-the-ahlc-september-2023 - Warns that abrupt aid cutoffs and revenue shocks risk collapsing essential PA services and security coordination, with destabilizing economic and social consequences. Presents evidence that blanket funding bans can harm civilians and undermine governance stability.
content.source_3: Hartzell, Caroline A., and Matthew Hoddie. Crafting Peace: Power-Sharing Institutions and the Negotiated Settlement of Civil Wars. Penn State University Press, 2007. https://www.psupress.org/books/titles/978-0-271-03219-1.html - Cross-national analysis finds that post-conflict power-sharing—including the inclusion of former belligerents in government—correlates with more durable peace. Suggests that categorical exclusion of armed actors from governance can impede conflict transformation.
content.source_4: U.S. Supreme Court, Holder v. Humanitarian Law Project, 561 U.S. 1 (2010). https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/09pdf/08-1498.pdf - Held that even coordinated training and advice to designated terrorist organizations—aimed at nonviolent aims—constitutes prohibited “material support.” Highlights the legal risk that any engagement with a unity government containing an FTO could expose donors and implementers to criminal liability, bolstering arguments for non-funding.
content.source_5: UNOPS, “Gaza Reconstruction Mechanism (GRM).” https://www.unops.org/news-and-stories/feature/gaza-reconstruction-mechanism - Describes an internationally monitored system allowing donors to channel materials and funds for civilian reconstruction in Gaza with safeguards to mitigate diversion to Hamas. Provides a model for ring-fenced, compliance-heavy assistance as an alternative to blanket funding bans.
content.source_6: The Carter Center, “Final Report: Observing the 2006 Palestinian Legislative Council Elections.” https://www.cartercenter.org/resources/pdfs/news/peace_publications/election_reports/palestine-020106-finalrpt.pdf - Found the 2006 elections to be competitive and broadly in line with international standards; subsequent donor boycotts of the Hamas-led government raised concerns about undermining democratic choice. Offers a democratic legitimacy perspective challenging categorical funding prohibitions.
